The auÂ­thor conÂ­cludes that afÂ­ï¬‚uÂ­ent counÂ­tries are conÂ­sumÂ­ing too much meat. In a sense, huÂ­mans used to comÂ­pleÂ­ment their diÂ­ets with meat. We now domÂ­iÂ­nate our diÂ­ets with meat.

Evolutionary heritage and preagricultural meat consumption

Humans have abÂ­norÂ­mally large brains. To supÂ­port the growth of this orÂ­gan, it is hyÂ­pothÂ­eÂ­sized that anÂ­other orÂ­gan had to be downÂ­sized. Even among rich European houseÂ­holds in the late 18th cenÂ­tury, eatÂ­ing meat was quite rare. Peasants may only have eaten meat 2 or 3 times a year.

Around the 1930s, meat supÂ­plied only around 2% of all food enÂ­ergy.

Modern dietary transition and its outcomes

Diets started to change in Europe around the mid 19th cenÂ­tury. In the Western world, we mostly only eat beef, pork, or poulÂ­try. The conÂ­sumpÂ­tion of other meats has been steadily deÂ­clinÂ­ing over the years.

By the end of the 20th cenÂ­tury, the popÂ­uÂ­laÂ­tion of afÂ­ï¬‚uÂ­ent counÂ­tries repÂ­reÂ­sented only one-ï¬fth of the global toÂ­tal but proÂ­duced and conÂ­sumed two-ï¬fths of all red meat and three-ï¬fths of all poulÂ­try.

Animal feeding requirements

There is a tradeÂ­off when feedÂ­ing grain crops to anÂ­iÂ­mals. For exÂ­amÂ­ple, if foodÂ­grains were culÂ­tiÂ­vated inÂ­stead of feed crops, we would proÂ­duce more diÂ­gestible enÂ­ergy and proÂ­tein. Yet, anÂ­iÂ­mals proÂ­duce higher qualÂ­ity proÂ­tein.

Cows suck at turnÂ­ing feed grain into meat. They conÂ­sume about 50% more enÂ­ergy than pigs. Chickens are the best conÂ­vertÂ­ers of plant-to-anÂ­iÂ­mal proÂ­teinâ€“at about 20% efÂ­ï¬Â­ciency.

Overall, the three maÂ­jor anÂ­iÂ­malsâ€“cows, pigs, and chickÂ­ensâ€“are exÂ­tremely inÂ­efÂ­ï¬Â­cient at creÂ­atÂ­ing proÂ­tein. About 80 to 96% of plant proÂ­tein conÂ­sumed is not conÂ­verted to anÂ­iÂ­mal proÂ­tein.

Environmental consequences of meat production

Nowadays, huÂ­mans eat so much meat that doÂ­mesÂ­tic anÂ­iÂ­mals have beÂ­come the domÂ­iÂ­nant class of verÂ­teÂ­brates on Earth. In sumÂ­mary, there's a lot of cows.

With curÂ­rent crop yields and feedÂ­ing pracÂ­tices, the enÂ­tire world canÂ­not eat meat at the same rate as the afÂ­ï¬‚uÂ­ent counÂ­tries. To achieve meat-eatÂ­ing for all, we would need to make adÂ­vances in bioÂ­engiÂ­neerÂ­ing.

The numÂ­ber of feed crops fed to anÂ­iÂ­mals could feed apÂ­proxÂ­iÂ­mately 3 bilÂ­lion adÂ­diÂ­tional huÂ­mans. In a way, it's temptÂ­ing to try switch peoÂ­ple to a mostly plant-based diet. One needs large amounts of waÂ­ter to raise anÂ­iÂ­mals and grow feed crops. Thus, meat/â€‹grain trade can benÂ­eÂ­ï¬t counÂ­tries with scarce waÂ­ter reÂ­sources. This sitÂ­uÂ­aÂ­tion can poÂ­tenÂ­tially set up a comÂ­parÂ­aÂ­tive adÂ­vanÂ­tage in trade for waÂ­ter-rich proÂ­ducÂ­ers.

The main facÂ­tor limÂ­itÂ­ing the size and denÂ­sity of anÂ­iÂ­mal proÂ­ducÂ­tion is our inÂ­abilÂ­ity to disÂ­pose of wastes efÂ­fecÂ­tively.

Health implications of meat production and consumption

Most of the anÂ­iÂ­mals we eat are soÂ­cial anÂ­iÂ­malsâ€“and this leads to varÂ­iÂ­ous ethÂ­iÂ­cal dilemÂ­mas. Modern farmÂ­ing techÂ­niques don't exÂ­actly take good care of the anÂ­iÂ­mals.

Meatpacking is one of the most danÂ­gerÂ­ous ocÂ­cuÂ­paÂ­tions in the counÂ­try. In 2000, about 25% of meatÂ­packÂ­ing emÂ­ployÂ­ees, or about 4 times the priÂ­vate inÂ­dusÂ­try avÂ­erÂ­age, had nonÂ­faÂ­tal inÂ­juries or illÂ­ness. Serious inÂ­juries ocÂ­cur at about 5 times the priÂ­vate inÂ­dusÂ­try avÂ­erÂ­age.

Obesity in adults was staÂ­ble beÂ­tween 1960 and 1980â€“at about 25% of the popÂ­uÂ­laÂ­tion. In the 1980s, this perÂ­centÂ­age rose by 8 points. By the 1990s, every third adult in the United States was obese.

Many meals in the United States are high in fat. The auÂ­thor blames beef's high lipid conÂ­tent and our prefÂ­erÂ­ence for fast food.

We use more anÂ­tibiÂ­otics on anÂ­iÂ­mals than on huÂ­mans. This pracÂ­tice could poÂ­tenÂ­tially lead to bacÂ­teÂ­ria gainÂ­ing imÂ­muÂ­nity to esÂ­senÂ­tial anÂ­tibiÂ­otics.

Possible adjustments

During the last four decades, huÂ­mans have tripled our meat proÂ­ducÂ­tion.

Over time, our diÂ­ets have beÂ­come less disÂ­ciÂ­plinedâ€“which has gone hand-in-hand with obese peoÂ­ple claimÂ­ing to be vicÂ­tims.

There is no sciÂ­enÂ­tifÂ­iÂ­cally deÂ­fenÂ­siÂ­ble reaÂ­son for strict vegÂ­eÂ­tarÂ­iÂ­anÂ­ism. Conversely, there is no deÂ­fenÂ­siÂ­ble reaÂ­son for the amount of meat curÂ­rently preÂ­vailÂ­ing in Western diÂ­ets. These meaty diÂ­ets do not make peoÂ­ple healthÂ­ier or proÂ­long their lives.
